head.title: Judah Aims to Keep Title and Build Status

hedline.hl1: Judah Aims to Keep Title and Build Status

abstract.p: Zab Judah discusses his preparations to defend his International Boxing Federation Junior welterweight championship against Terronn Millett on Aug 5 (M)

block.p: Some people view Zab Judah's next fight as a test. Judah views it as a steppingstone.

Putting his unbeaten record (23-0, 17 knockouts) on the line, Judah is eager for his coming International Boxing Federation junior welterweight championship bout against Terronn Millett, Aug. 5, at the Mohegan Sun Casino in Uncasville, Conn.
Some people view Zab Judah's next fight as a test. Judah views it as a steppingstone.

Putting his unbeaten record (23-0, 17 knockouts) on the line, Judah is eager for his coming International Boxing Federation junior welterweight championship bout against Terronn Millett, Aug. 5, at the Mohegan Sun Casino in Uncasville, Conn.

Millett (22-1-1, 17 knockouts) is no pushover. He is the former I.B.F. junior welterweight champion, but Millett was stripped of his title earlier this year after he broke his right hand and was unable to make a mandatory defense against Judah.
Now Judah is the champion, and he intends to remain one.

''I'm not going to make any predictions, but I'm in the best shape of my life,'' said Judah, a 22-year-old Brooklyn native, who has quickly earned a reputation as one of the world's most talented young boxers. ''I'm the best and I'm going to show the world that.''
Millett intends to be a problem.

''Zab's somewhat quick, but he's not as blazing quick as the media says he is,'' said Millett, speaking on a conference call yesterday. ''He may hit hard, but I hit hard. Once we get in the middle of the ring, we'll see.''

Judah won the title in February with a fourth-round knockout of Jan Bergman. But Judah was not overly impressive in his last fight, winning a decision against the journeyman Junior Witter in Scotland.

But Judah's hand speed and footwork have been compared with a former great champion, Pernell Whitaker. Judah became a protege of Whitaker's, and he learned his lessons well. Judah compiled an amateur record of 110-5, and he was a five-time Golden Gloves champion. Since turning professional, Judah has enjoyed mostly one-sided victories.
Lou Duva, who managed Whitaker and now manages Judah, believes comparisons between Judah and Whitaker are valid.

''I had the same feeling when I took over Pernell Whitaker as an amateur,'' Duva said. ''Zab can do anything Pernell Whitaker could, and maybe better. Zab Judah is going to a great champion, but he needs to fight a good fighter, and that's why we're fighting Millett.''
